action.action-desc: Ms. Sewell of Alabama (for herself and Mr. Danny K. Davis of Illinois) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to eliminate the school voucher State tax credit loophole by limiting the double benefit of charitable contributions.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Public Funds for Public Schools Act.

section.header: Elimination of school voucher State tax credit loophole by limiting the double benefit of charitable contributions

subsection.text: Section 170(f) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Limitation on double benefit in the case of State school voucher tax benefits

subparagraph.text: The amount of any charitable contribution otherwise taken into account under this section shall be reduced by any State school voucher tax benefit with respect to such contribution.

For purposes of this paragraph, the term State school voucher tax benefit means the aggregate amount of any State income tax credits, and excess State income tax deductions, provided to the taxpayer by a State for any contribution to a specified school voucher organization.
For purposes of this paragraph, the term excess State income tax deduction means the product of—

clause.text: the highest rate of State income tax applicable to the taxpayer for the taxable year, multiplied by

subclause.text: the State income tax deduction provided to the taxpayer with respect to contributions by the taxpayer to specified school voucher organizations, over

subparagraph.text: For purposes of this paragraph, the term specified school voucher organization means any organization the primary purpose of which is the provision of vouchers, scholarships, or other funds, for the expenses of students to attend elementary or secondary schools.

For purposes of this paragraph, any State benefit which is economically equivalent to a tax credit (including any payment) shall be treated as a State income tax credit for purposes of this paragraph and any State benefit which is economically equivalent to a State income tax deduction (including any exclusion from gross income) shall be treated as a State income tax deduction for purposes of this paragraph.

paragraph.header: Special rule for contributions of built-in gain property to specified school voucher organizations

subparagraph.text: In the case of any contribution by the taxpayer of built-in gain property to a specified school voucher organization, such contribution shall be treated for purposes of this title as though such property were sold by the taxpayer at its fair market value immediately before such contribution and the amount of such fair market value were contributed by the taxpayer as a cash contribution to the specified school voucher organization.

clause.text: The term built-in gain property means any property if, immediately before the contribution of such property, the fair market value of such property exceeds the adjusted basis of such property.
The term specified school voucher organization has the meaning given such term in paragraph (19).

subsection.text: The amendment made by this section shall apply to charitable contributions made in taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
